titleStmt.title: Variants of the retention or changes in the interdentals
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for the interdentals.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found

item.label: Partially kept: ḏ and ṯ kept
Partially kept: ḏ and ḏ̣ kept
Reflected as postdentals with retention of ḏ̣ in some lexical items
ṯ is reflected as labiodental f but ḏ and ḏ̣ are reflected as postdentals d and ḍ

wib:featureValueObservation.note: The interdentals (plain and emphatic) are currently in a state of variability with their stop counterparts. The origin of the variability in Amman is the contact between Jordanian dialects, which have interdentals, and Madanī Palestinian dialects, which do not. In the case of the plain interdentals, /ṯ/ and /ḏ/, many speakers (especially the male speakers) use them variably with /t/ and /d/. The emphatic interdental,/ḏ̣/, shows a considerably lower degree of variation with the stop variant /ḍ/ in the speech of the same speaker, i.e., the speakers tend to use either one or the other. The speakers who use the emphatic interdental are exclusively of Jordanian or Fallāḥī Palestinian origin and are most often male speakers, while those who use the stop counterpart can be from anywhere and of either sex (quote from al-Wer 2007a).
/ḏ/>/d/ among the farmers of the Hijazi group; Banu Salim of the Hijazi group use /f/ instead of /ṯ/ in the word ǧadaf "grave".
they are retained, but sometimes younger speakers use the variants t and d
ex taken from text
ex taken from text
Some instances of /ḏ/ reflected as /ṯ/, e.g. ḥaṯa ´to throw sand or ashes´
few exceptions in words that are used in Syria, e.g. haẓẓ (luck)
ḏ̣ (along with ḍ) is reflected as a voiceless emphatic /ṯ/̣ , which in the upper part of Ǧabal Fayfa shifts to the labiodental f
in a number of cases, especially demonstratives, interdentals are pronounced as alveolar stops: hāda, dāk, etc.
Some instances of /ḏ/ reflected as /ṯ/, e.g. muʔannaṯah `feminine gender`
considered as used in villages
considered as urban; used rather by Christians and women
hāḏ̣a
hāḏ̣a

There are a few exceptions, sometimes t is used for ṯ for example in talǧ (ice, snow) and s is used for ṯ in lexemes which are borrowed from a dialect without interdentals such as masalan (for instance). Z is sometimes used for ḏ like in kaza "such and so". Ḏ̣ in some words is replaced by ẓ like in mwaẓẓaf "civil servant". The sg. masc. demonstrative (hā-)ḏa (this) is not velarized.
ẓ occurs in loanwords from MSA or Egyptian Arabic, for instance ẓābiṭ 'officer'.

There are a few exceptions, sometimes t is used for ṯ for example in talǧ (ice, snow) and in some lonas from MSA the reflex for ṯ is s e.g. ḥadīs (modern). Z is sometimes used for ḏ like in kizāluḳ "as well". Ḏ̣ in some words is reflected as ẓ like in ẓubbāṭ (officer). The sg. masc. demonstrative (hā-)ḏa (this) is not velarized.
ẓ occurs in loanwords from MSA or Egyptian Arabic, for instance ẓābiṭ 'officer'.

There are a few exceptions, sometimes t is used for ṯ for example in talǧ (ice, snow) and s is used for ṯ in lexemes which are borrowed from a dialect without interdentals such as masalan (for instance). Z is sometimes used for ḏ like in kaza "such and so". Ḏ̣ in some words is replaced by ẓ like in mwaẓẓaf "civil servant". The sg. masc. demonstrative (hā-)ḏa (this) is not velarized.
ẓ occurs in loanwords from MSA or Egyptian Arabic, for instance ẓābiṭ 'officer'.

Z is sometimes used for ḏ like in kizāluḳ "as well". Ḏ̣ in some words is reflected as ẓ like in ẓubbāṭ (officer). The sg. masc. demonstrative (hā-)ḏa (this) is not velarized.

There are a few exceptions, sometimes t is used for ṯ for example in talǧ (ice, snow) and s is used for ṯ in lexemes which are borrowed from a dialect without interdentals such as masalan (for instance). Z is sometimes used for ḏ like in kaza "such and so". Ḏ̣ in some words is replaced by ẓ like in mwaẓẓaf "civil servant". The sg. masc. demonstrative (hā-)ḏa (this) is not velarized.

Some younger speakers subsititute the interdentals with dentals, perhaps due to the popularity of Egyptian media and the sizeable population of Egyptians in Benghazi
The interdentals are retained by the bedouin speakers
The interdentals are reflected as post dentals by the sedentary speakers

cit.quote: the call to the noon prayer

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Deduced from examples and only for ḏ
Deduced from examples
The interdentals are only retained in rural Hijazi
The interdentals are only reflected as postdentals in urban Hijazi
Urban speakers tend to realise ḏ as ḍ.
Deduced from examples, no examples of ḏ̣ were elicited
ṯ is sometimes also realized s, e.g. selāsa ('three').

cit.quote: saline plants on which camels graze

wib:featureValueObservation.note: ḏ is generally realised ẓ.
ḏ is both pronounced d and [ɗ](pharyngealized dental implosive, e.g. nuhúɗɗ ("we take")).
At least one speaker in the village of Hsi-Sālem realises ṯ as f.
La Rosa 2021: 8-9 reports instances of interdentals, probably because of influence from Tunis.
ḏ̣ and ḏ > ḏ, ṯ = ṯ
generally unstable, partly interdentals kept, partly postdentals
exist in some Berber words
one example where interdental > sibilant: ksir (kaṯīr)

ḍ and ḏ̣ fall together and are pronounced as ḍ
